items.title: Trump pushes 245% tariff on China
items.summary:
- The US has increased tariffs on Chinese imports to a maximum of 245% as of April 15, 2025.
- This decision follows China's retaliatory actions amid an ongoing trade conflict between the US and China.
- The tariff increase is accompanied by an executive order from President Trump to investigate national security risks due to reliance on imported critical minerals.
- This marks a significant escalation in the trade dispute, following a pattern of retaliatory tariffs between the two nations.
- Approximately 20 million Chinese workers are directly affected by US-bound exports subjected to these tariffs.
- The Tax Foundation forecasts a long-run US GDP reduction of 0.8% and a loss of about 740,000 American jobs due to the tariffs.
- The average US household could face a tax increase of $1,280 in 2025 as tariff costs are passed on to consumers.
- Small businesses are particularly vulnerable to tariff uncertainty, leading to cancellation of orders and shipment disruptions.

items.title: Xendit launches free VC-startup database in SEA
items.summary:
- Xendit introduces a free database featuring over 150 active venture capital firms in Southeast Asia to connect founders with investors.
- The database includes firms investing in Indonesia, Singapore, Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines, updated regularly.
- The initiative comes at a time when Southeast Asia's funding has significantly declined, hitting a three-year low of $4.56 billion in 2024, a 42% drop from the previous year.

items.title: Nvidia said to keep Chinese clients in dark of US export rules
items.summary:
- Nvidia is reportedly informing its Chinese clients about U.S. export regulations only on a need-to-know basis.
- This secrecy may be to avoid complications arising from those regulations.
- The U.S. has enforced strict export controls that affect technology sales to China, particularly in semiconductors.

items.title: CreateAI releases world’s first genAI-made music video
items.author: Kelly Yu
items.summary:
- Chinese-Canadian singer Kelly Yu releases the world's first music video created entirely using generative AI (genAI) technology, titled "Werewolf".
- The video features AI-generated visuals along with human-drawn elements, showcasing a fairy-tale theme with castles and werewolves.
- CreateAI, the company behind the project, reported a nearly 50% reduction in production time and significant cost savings.
- The video represents a shift in the music video landscape, echoing the historical evolution from traditional performances to digital art.
- There's a growing industry sentiment that AI can enhance, rather than replace, human creativity through collaboration.
- The rise of AI in music production brings ethical questions around copyright and compensation for AI-generated content, especially as streaming platforms move towards incorporating AI technology.

items.title: SAIC’s new EV brand with Huawei to debut Apr-Jun 2025
items.summary:
- SAIC Motor and Huawei launched a new EV brand called Shangjie.
- First model slated for debut in autumn 2025 (April-June).
- The collaboration involves styling design, intelligent cockpit tech, smart driving, and more.
- Joint venture team consists of over 5,000 members focusing on operations and technology.
- Partnership comes amid SAIC's 93% drop in net profit in 2024.
- Targeting a competitive price range of RMB 150,000 to 250,000 ($20,600-$34,400) for the Shangjie brand.
- Aims to attract younger buyers in China’s evolving EV market.

items.title: Korean AI startup Upstage expands globally
items.author: Sung Kim
items.summary:
- Upstage is expanding its AI operations globally, focusing on enhancing business productivity.
- Co-founder and CEO Sung Kim introduced two AI tools: Document Parse (DP) and Solar, with DP outperforming tools from major providers.
- Upstage has secured substantial funding, raising $72 million in Series B funding in early 2024, totaling over $100 million in investments.
- Document Parse offers a 99% accuracy rate for OCR technology, targeting industries like insurance and finance.
- Upstage's development includes a Thai language LLM and aims for localized AI models in line with national values.

items.title: Israeli software company acquired by US private equity firm
items.summary:
[An Israeli software company has been acquired by a US private equity firm.]
[The acquisition is part of a trend of increasing foreign investment in Israeli tech.]
[Details about the financial terms of the deal remain undisclosed.]

items.title: Volkswagen VC arm joins battery tech firm’s $30m funding round
items.summary:
- Volkswagen's venture capital arm participates in a $30 million funding round for a battery technology company.
- This investment highlights the automaker's commitment to sustainable technologies.
- The funding is intended to enhance battery innovation and production capabilities.

items.title: SoftBank-backed B2B marketplace bags $11.7m from Cornerstone
items.summary:
- Gurugram-based B2B marketplace OfBusiness raised $11.7 million from Cornerstone Ventures for its planned IPO in H2 2025.
- Funding comes from Cornerstone's $200 million second fund, which closed its first round at $40 million in January 2025.
- OfBusiness aims to enhance digital adoption and financing access for SMEs in manufacturing and infrastructure sectors.
- Founded in 2016, OfBusiness has raised approximately $878 million from various investors including Alpha Wave Ventures II, Tiger Global, and SoftBank.
- The B2B e-commerce market in India is expected to grow significantly, projected to reach $200 billion by 2030 from just $9 billion in 2022.
- The MSME sector contributes 31% to India's GDP and 43% of exports, with growth expected to rise to approximately 7.5 crores by 2025.

items.title: American shoppers turn to Chinese ecommerce on tariff fears
Series SEA: Who’s investing in the region’s AI startups?
items.summary:
- An overview of active investors in Southeast Asia's AI startups over the past two years.
- Firms are ranked by the number of deals done, highlighting those that invested in three or more companies.
- The data aims to provide a better understanding of the impact of each firm's investments in the region's AI sector.

items.title: Shein’s production shift cuts orders for Chinese suppliers
items.summary:
- Suppliers in Guangzhou, China, report a significant decrease in orders from Shein, with some experiencing a 50% drop.
- Shein is shifting production to Vietnam to mitigate US tariff challenges after the de minimis exemption for Chinese imports was removed.
- While Shein denies moving capacity out of China, it encourages larger suppliers to establish operations in Vietnam by offering incentives.
- Experts caution that this shift could disrupt Shein's efficient business model, potentially leading to higher costs and longer turnaround times for goods.
- The removal of the de minimis exemption affects the entire fast fashion sector, potentially increasing apparel prices by 64% in the short term.
- The reported changes may impact millions of Chinese workers linked to U.S. exports and showcase how tariff policies are reshaping regional manufacturing.

items.title: Israeli AI startup raises $5.75m to boost brand visibility
items.author: Imri Marcus, Dvir Dvash, Uri Gafni
items.summary:
- Brandlight, an AI-driven brand visibility startup, raised $5.75 million in funding.
- The funding round included contributions from Cardumen Capital and G20 Ventures with notable advisors.
- Brandlight optimizes data for AI engines, offering tools for managing brand visibility in AI-generated search results.

items.title: ASML Q1 orders miss forecast as AI, trade worries grow
items.summary:
- ASML Holding NV reported Q1 2025 orders of €3.94 billion, missing the forecast of €4.82 billion.
- The company maintained its full-year sales forecast of €30 billion to €35 billion despite weak orders.
- Concerns arise from slowing demand for AI chips and potential impacts of US trade policy, although some semiconductor gear is exempt from new tariffs.
- The semiconductor market is projected to grow 19.0% in 2024, driven by increases in Memory and Logic segments.
- Geopolitical tensions are reshaping global semiconductor investment patterns, with U.S. manufacturing capacity expected to triple by 2032.
- Despite competition and order weaknesses, the EUV lithography market is projected to grow significantly by 2029.

items.title: Unicommerce CTO resigns after 8 years
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Bhupinder Garg, CTO of Unicommerce, resigned on April 15, 2025, citing personal reasons.
- His resignation was confirmed on April 16, following a tenure that began in October 2017.
- Garg was instrumental in expanding Unicommerce's product offerings to include D2C and B2B solutions.
- Before joining Unicommerce, Garg had nearly two decades of experience with companies like Snapdeal and Amazon.
- Unicommerce has promoted Ankit Jain and Rachit Srivastava to leadership roles in engineering and product development.
- The company’s financial performance showed revenue growth to INR 32.7 crore in Q3 FY25, despite a stock price decline of 28.43% year-to-date.
- Garg’s departure comes less than a year after Unicommerce's IPO in August 2024, highlighting leadership continuity amid market challenges.

items.title: Indian logistics firm Zippee launches a 60-min delivery service
items.summary:
- Zippee has launched Blaze, a 60-minute delivery service for ecommerce marketplaces in India.
- The service is currently active in NCR, Bangalore, and Mumbai, with future plans for expansion.
- Blaze will deliver across various categories such as supplements, food, home decor, and fashion.
- Founded in 2021, Zippee operates dark stores and fleets in 13 cities, offering same-day and two-hour deliveries as well.
- The startup aims to reduce long delivery times associated with traditional couriers and expects 17% of shipments to utilize Blaze by Q2 FY2026.
- The quick commerce sector in India is anticipated to grow significantly, potentially reaching $303.3 billion by 2030.

items.title: Stripe brings WeChat Pay to businesses in 20 countries
items.summary:
- Global payments platform Stripe has partnered with Tencent to integrate WeChat Pay into Stripe Terminal across 20 countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Singapore, the UK, and the US.
- This integration allows businesses using Stripe to accept WeChat Pay for both online and in-person transactions, catering to Chinese consumers in various physical stores and e-commerce platforms.
- The move addresses the increasing demand from international businesses to accommodate Chinese travelers, enabling merchants to process QR code-based payments.

items.title: Tencent Cloud to open third data center in Japan
Indian regulator probes EV loan misuse by BluSmart co-founder
Why small shops ditch merchant accounts in the Philippines
items.summary:
- Only 10% of daily transactions at Nerissa Elamil's vegetable shop are cashless, using her personal GCash e-wallet.
- A study indicates 90% of 980,000 MSMEs in the Philippines don’t use formal merchant accounts.
- Despite cashless payments dominating formal transactions, many businesses prefer cash due to costs associated with merchant accounts.
- GCash, the largest e-wallet, charges 2-3% per transaction for merchant accounts, while personal accounts incur no fees but have lower monthly limits.
- Some entrepreneurs manage multiple personal accounts as a workaround to avoid fees associated with merchant accounts.

items.title: Nasdaq-listed Semler Scientific to raise $500m for bitcoin buys
items.summary:
- Semler Scientific filed a registration statement to offer up to $500 million in securities for general corporate purposes, including bitcoin acquisitions.
- The company has already allocated $280.4 million to bitcoin, significantly exceeding its cash reserves of $14.92 million.
- Semler's bitcoin strategy comes amid a $29.75 million DOJ settlement related to False Claims Act violations, balancing aggressive investment with regulatory challenges.

items.title: SK Telecom launches auto in-flight Wi-Fi on Korean Air
TikTok tests new feature for location reviews in videos
items.summary:
- TikTok is testing a new feature that displays location reviews in the comments section of videos.
- The feature, named the 'Reviews' tab, allows users to see star ratings, written reviews, and photos for tagged locations.
- This update aims to enhance search functionality and compete with platforms like Google, though its wider rollout is yet unconfirmed.

items.title: Indian communications unicorn Gupshup lays off 200 employees
items.summary:
- Gupshup laid off approximately 200 employees as part of restructuring earlier this month.
- This is the second round of layoffs in five months; about 300 employees were let go in December 2024.
- The company aims to improve efficiency and profitability, having undergone a total net headcount reduction of 300 over 18 months.
- Insiders predict another round of layoffs in June 2025, which Gupshup has denied, asserting it is already profitable.
- Investors are shifting focus from growth metrics to profitability, demonstrated by a significant markdown of the company's valuation from $1.4 billion to $486 million.

items.title: Grok adds canvas-style tool for creating docs, apps
items.summary:
• On April 15, 2025, xAI announced Grok Studio, a new feature of its chatbot Grok.
• Grok Studio allows users to edit and create documents, code, and basic applications.
• The tool is available for both free and paid users on Grok.com.
• Grok Studio is comparable to Canvas for ChatGPT and Artifacts for Claude.
• It integrates with Google Drive, indicating a push for contextual AI assistance within productivity tools.
• Industry trends show a shift to collaborative workspaces and specialized applications in AI development, with substantial growth potential identified by McKinsey.

items.title: Medium reaffirms commitment to DEI despite political pressure
items.summary:
- Medium confirms its commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) despite rising political pressure.
- The platform emphasizes the importance of diverse voices for enriching conversations and enhancing understanding.
- Medium aims to create a safe environment while prohibiting hate speech and misinformation.
- The company contrasts its commitment with other firms that are scaling back DEI initiatives, citing financial advantages of diversity.
- Statistics show persistent representation gaps in the tech industry, with Black professionals and women underrepresented.
- Companies with diverse teams report higher revenues from innovation, highlighting diversity as a competitive advantage.
- Medium's mission includes promoting diverse perspectives as essential for effective product development.

items.title: HK-based AI safety startup viAct nets $7.3m series A
items.summary:
- ViAct, an AI company in Hong Kong, raised US$7.3 million in a series A funding round.
- The round was led by Dublin-based Venturewave Capital, with participation from Singtel Innov8, Korea Investment Partners, and PolyU Entrepreneurship Investment Fund.
- ViAct utilizes AI and computer vision to monitor and predict workplace hazards.
- The funding will help advance ViAct's AI technology and facilitate expansion into regions such as the Middle East.
- Founded in 2016, ViAct aims to enhance workplace safety through an integrated AI platform.

items.title: Swiggy partners with Indian gov’t to boost gig economy jobs
items.summary:
- Swiggy signed a memorandum of understanding with India’s Ministry of Labour and Employment to list gig job roles on the National Career Service (NCS) portal.
- The partnership aims to increase visibility for gig work opportunities, expected to create 1.2 million jobs in 2-3 years.
- Labour Minister Mansukh Mandaviya emphasized the partnership's role in expanding access to flexible job opportunities in the gig economy.

items.title: Tesla halts China imports for Cybercab, Semi parts as tariff hikes
items.summary:
- Tesla suspends shipments of components from China for the Cybercab and Semi due to tariff hikes.
- Tariffs increased from 34% to 145% as of April 9, 2025, making costs unsustainable.
- The suspension could delay trial production for both models, initially planned for October 2025, with mass production scheduled for 2026.

items.title: Tainan to test AI facial recognition pilot at ATMs in May 2025
items.summary:
- Taiwanese city of Tainan will launch a pilot program in May 2025 using AI-driven facial recognition technology at select ATMs to combat fraud.
- The new system prompts users with a voice recording to remove masks or helmets for identification, with an alarm sounding if identification fails in 10–15 seconds.
- This system will not block transactions for unidentified users but aims to deter suspicious behavior through alerts.

items.title: Chinese sellers livestream discounts after US tariffs hit
items.summary:
- Chinese sellers are leveraging [Rednote](https://www.techinasia.com/news/chinese-sellers-livestream-discounts-tariffs-hit) to target US markets post-tariff increases.
- US tariffs have escalated as high as 145%, prompting discounts up to 90% on products like rice cookers and toasters.
- China is promoting local sales with platforms like JD.com investing billions to support domestic distribution.
- Observers note that livestreaming may be more of a marketing tactic rather than a response to genuine overstock.
- The article discusses historical patterns of economic nationalism during trade disputes, particularly how consumer campaigns have evolved during tariff escalations.
- JD.com’s 200 billion yuan fund is part of a strategy to pivot from exports to domestic sales under the “dual circulation” policy, which aims to bolster home consumption while retaining export capacity.
- Social media trends indicate businesses are shifting to value-centric marketing during economic downturns, enhancing their visibility amid shrinking export opportunities.

items.title: Indian lab-grown diamond brand Jewelbox bags $3.2m pre-series A
Zuckerberg says he weighed Instagram spin-off in 2018
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Meta, testified that he considered spinning off Instagram in 2018 due to concerns that Instagram's success might harm Facebook's core network.
- He suggested that separation could address regulatory challenges and improve operational focus.
- The FTC's case alleges that Meta's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp contributed to monopolistic practices in social networking.

items.title: China debates rules for $59b in seized crypto assets
items.summary:
- China is discussing new rules for managing seized cryptocurrencies amid rising illegal use and related crimes.
- In 2023, cases of crypto-related crimes surged to involve 430.7 billion yuan (approximately $59 billion).
- Local governments currently sell confiscated cryptocurrencies through private firms, lacking unified regulations.
- The contradiction arises as China bans crypto trading while benefiting from its economic value through seized assets.
- Local governments’ revenues from penalties and confiscated assets reached a record 378 billion yuan ($59 billion) in 2023.
- This trend highlights a conflict between central government policies and local needs for revenue, especially during economic slowdowns.
- China’s approach to cryptocurrency diverges from global regulatory movements, contrasting with the U.S. and other nations fostering digital asset growth.

items.title: Australia’s 007 Venture Partners launches $3.25m startup fund
items.author: Bond Sudarta
items.summary:
- 007 Venture Partners has launched a AUD $5 million (US$3.25 million) early-stage fund.
- The fund aims to support startups addressing global challenges and will invest in 15 to 30 early-stage companies.
- Investment areas will include healthcare, small business empowerment, education, and climate solutions, aligning with the UN Sustainable Development Goals.
- The fund will connect companies with a global network from firms like Airbnb and Meta and target regions including the US, Australia, India, and emerging markets.
- The venture capital funding for impact startups has been declining, with a projected 36% drop in 2023 compared to 2022.
- The long-term trajectory for impact investing remains positive, with the market projected to reach $1 trillion by 2025.

items.title: Productivity platform Notion unveils AI email tool for Gmail users
items.summary:
- Notion launched Notion Mail, an AI-powered email client for Gmail users on April 15, 2025.
- The tool helps with organizing emails, drafting responses, scheduling meetings, and searching messages.
- Notion Mail integrates with Notion Calendar and allows customizable, AI-driven sorting of inboxes into topic-based folders.
- Available with free AI features under monthly limits or unlimited access via subscription.
- Notion Mail emphasizes modularity and customization over traditional email client design, enhancing user workflows significantly.

items.title: Ex-Tesla execs’ AI inventory startup Atomic secures $3m
items.author: Michael Rossiter, Neal Suidan
items.summary:
- Former Tesla employees Michael Rossiter and Neal Suidan launched a new company named [Atomic](https://www.techinasia.com/news/extesla-execs-ai-inventory-startup-atomic-secures-3m).
- The startup secured US$3 million in seed funding, led by DVx Ventures and Madrona Ventures to use AI for inventory planning and supply chain management.
- Atomic's technology allows businesses to simulate various inventory scenarios quickly.
- Pilot customers in consumer packaged goods, food and beverage, and apparel sectors achieved inventory cost reductions of 20% to 50%.
- The article also discusses the challenges of overautomation in manufacturing, particularly referencing Tesla's past issues and the importance of integrating human planners with AI technology.

items.title: Anthropic to launch voice assistant for Claude chatbot
items.summary:
- Anthropic is set to introduce a voice assistant feature for its Claude chatbot, anticipated to launch later this month on a limited basis.
- The feature will include three voice options: Airy, Mellow, and a British-accented voice named Buttery.
- The specific launch timeline is not confirmed, and no public comment has been made by Anthropic on these developments.

items.title: OpenAI Said to Build Social Media Platform
items.summary:
- OpenAI is reportedly developing a social media platform in its prototype phase, integrating AI features like ChatGPT’s image generation.
- CEO Sam Altman is seeking feedback; it's unclear if it will be a standalone app or part of ChatGPT.
- The launch could intensify competition with major players like Elon Musk’s X and Meta.
- The move could help OpenAI access user-generated content, closing a data gap compared to competitors.
- The initiative reflects a broader industry trend of convergence between AI developers and social media platforms.

items.title: Nvidia hit with $5.5b charge as US limits chip exports to China
items.summary:
- The US imposed new licensing requirements on Nvidia for exporting H20 integrated circuits to China, effective April 9.
- Nvidia expects to incur charges of up to $5.5 billion in its first fiscal quarter of 2026, covering inventory and purchase commitments.
- Export restrictions are aimed at preventing H20 chips from being used in Chinese supercomputers and will remain indefinitely in place.
- The decision reflects ongoing concerns about technological decoupling and pushes for domestic semiconductor development in China.
- Nvidia's stock dropped 6% after the announcement, impacting other semiconductor companies similarly.

items.title: China’s rare earth export curbs may impact US military tech
items.summary:
- China has implemented export restrictions on seven rare earth elements critical to defense and technology.
- The restrictions require special licenses for export, potentially disrupting supply chains for U.S. companies.
- The restricted elements include samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, and yttrium.
- Historical patterns show China using rare earth exports as geopolitical leverage.
- China controls about 90% of global rare earth processing, creating challenges for alternative suppliers.
- Military applications, such as the F-35 jet, highlight national security risks due to reliance on Chinese processing.
- The U.S. Department of Defense has committed to developing a complete rare earth supply chain by 2027 but faces significant challenges.

items.title: Xpeng to deploy self-developed AI chip in its EVs this quarter
items.summary:
- Xpeng is launching its self-developed AI chip, Turing, in semi-autonomous cars this quarter.
- The Turing chip will enhance autonomous driving capabilities with level 4 features.
- Specific EV model integrating the chip has not been disclosed.
- CEO He Xiaopeng optimistic about gaining regulatory approval in Hong Kong and elsewhere.
- Current models, P7 sedan and G6 SUV, offer level 2+ semi-autonomous driving.
- Development of indigenous chips by Chinese manufacturers addresses supply chain vulnerabilities.
- Xpeng's Turing chip claims to outperform Nvidia’s Drive Orin X by three times in computing power.
- Different regulatory environments pose challenges for the global deployment of Xpeng's technology.
- The competition between Chinese and American autonomous vehicle developers is intensifying.

items.title: Capital SEA: Southeast Asia’s funding landscape
items.author: Yeo Cheng Yong, Terence Lee
items.summary:
- The article explores trends in Southeast Asia’s funding landscape, addressing questions about new active investors and outlier funding rounds.
- It is divided into two sections: **weekly update** for recent data points and **macro trends** for overall funding patterns.
- Visual content and in-depth analysis require subscription access to view detailed charts and graphics.

items.title: Trump’s tariffs: US chip makers may face $1b loss yearly
items.summary:
- Proposed U.S. tariffs may cost American semiconductor equipment manufacturers over $1 billion annually.
- Major companies like Applied Materials, Lam Research, and KLA could face losses of about $350 million each per year.
- Smaller firms, such as Onto Innovation, may incur additional costs in the tens of millions due to lost sales, tariff compliance, and sourcing alternative suppliers.
- The U.S. chip equipment industry has already seen revenue losses from previous export controls aiming to limit China’s advanced chip production.
- Historical examples show that tariffs often lead to unintended consequences, potentially weakening the competitive position of American firms.
- The total financial impact includes costs for reorganization, compliance, and sourcing alternatives, exceeding direct tariff payments.

items.title: Apple to revamp sales team as enterprise chief exits
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Mark Rogers, Apple’s vice president of Western Europe and global enterprise sales, is leaving after 27 years.
- Responsibilities will be redistributed; Juan Castellanos will oversee Western Europe, and Vivek Thakkar will manage global enterprise sales.
- Rogers' departure aligns with Apple's shift towards a diversified revenue model, particularly in services, which now contributes significantly to revenue.

items.title: Xpeng’s X9 electric van eyes Europe after outselling Alphard
items.summary:
- Xpeng’s X9 electric van has outperformed Toyota's Alphard in sales.
- The company plans to enter the European market following this success.
- Xpeng aims to broaden its electric vehicle offerings in response to competitive demand.

items.title: Draper Associates backs neurotech startup’s $19m raise
items.summary:
- Phantom Neuro has raised US$19 million to develop its implantable technology for prosthetic limb control.
- The funding round was led by Ottobock and included participation from Breakout Ventures, Draper Associates, Actual VC, and Brown Advisory.
- Phantom Neuro's total funding now amounts to US$28 million, with its valuation undisclosed.
- The company's device translates nerve signals from amputees’ phantom limbs to facilitate prosthetic movements, initially targeting arms, with plans for legs and robots in the future.
- Challenges in prosthetic adoption include a 23-26% rejection rate for upper limb prosthetics due to comfort and sensory feedback issues.
- Phantom aims to achieve 94% accuracy and rapid calibration of 10 minutes to enhance user satisfaction and adoption rates.

items.title: Malaysia’s U Mobile partners with Huawei for 5G rollout
items.summary:
- U Mobile partners with Huawei and ZTE for Malaysia's 5G network deployment using a dual network model.
- Huawei will manage West Malaysia, while ZTE will cover East Malaysia, targeting 80% coverage within 12 months and 90% in the following year.
- The wholesale rates for U Mobile will be similar to current 5G operator Digital Nasional Berhad, at RM30,000 (US$6,300) per Gbps per month.

items.title: Singapore DeFi startup hits $400m valuation after token funding
items.author: Brandon Goh
items.summary:
- Treehouse Finance, a decentralized finance startup in Singapore, achieved a US$400 million fully diluted token valuation after a funding round.
- The funding was structured as a Simple Agreement for Future Tokens (SAFT), with the lead investor being a venture arm of a major financial services firm managing over US$500 billion in assets.
- Founded in 2021, Treehouse has over 30,000 unique wallet holders and 120,000 ETH in deposits, targeting the $600 trillion fixed income market in decentralized finance.

items.title: Adobe invests in UK-based AI video startup Synthesia
